The lemma Bicategory.whisker_exchange is not a simp lemma. I don't quite understand this, as to me it does not seem to conflict with the simp normal-form that is described in Bicategory/Basic. However I trust that the people who implemented realized that this is a bad idea to have as a simp lemma for whatever reason.

However, whenever a bicategory instance is added, one must show whisker_exchange. So for automation this is somewhat unfortunate. In simple cases (when the bicategory is constructed from another already existing one), whisker_exchange will be something like ext; simp; exact whisker_exchange _ _ where whisker_exchange gets applied for that other bicategory. It would be nice to have this automated. So I'm wondering, do people think it would be a good idea to add whisker_exchange as an unsafe aesop rule? I don't have much experience with aesop though, so I can't really tell if this is a bad idea or not (and it seems to me that there are 0 unsafe aesop rules added in the category theory library... So maybe this is a sign I'm trying to do something shady).
and in case people don't see obvious issues with this, I can try adding it to the bicategory library and run bench to see what happens.

This was discussed several times. My understanding is that there is no particular reason to favour whisker_exchange over the same lemma in the other direction. If this helps automation locally, it would suffice to make it a local simp lemma.
Okay but was it also discussed wether to add it as an aesop rule?
If I understood correctly when you said it was discussed already, this was whether it should be a simp lemma or not, but maybe I misunderstood this.

I remember that at some point I fiddled locally with unsafe aesop rules with similar kind of lemmas (perhaps even this one!), but never really got that to get automation un-stuck in the cases I were interested in. It might be user error.

On the other hand, I think whisker_exchange (for monoidal categories and bicategories) is a perfect fit for a grind _=_ lemma, but this alone won’t suffice and we probably need way more annotations before we can get grind to a satisfying place for bicategories and monoidal categories (I think it has a lot of potential there, though!)
Okay, that's good to know, thanks a lot!
Then I will just wait for grind to save me at some point in the future :)
